ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much in this course about the rise of mass incarceration. I learned what role each president since Lyndon Johnson has played in the shaping of the modern carceral state, the failures of liberal reformers, the role of the media in generating a moral panic about young Black people in cities, and a wide variety of preemptive policing practices that create crime rather than prevent it. This course also covered a history of Black resistance to mass incarceration that was very inspiring and generative, especially in the last few weeks of the semester.
I gained an entirely new, richer perspective on the history of crime control in the US from the 1960s on.

This course will teach you how to think critically about the history of policing and incarceration with a focus on 60s-70s until present. You will learn how pose thoughtful questions to the class and better understand which types of policies got us to where we are today.

An understanding of the local, state, and federal approaches to urban policy that created mass incarceration throughout the latter half of the 20th century; critiques of the carceral state and alternatives, including abolition

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are Prof. Hinton's incredible insights/endless knowledge,  the readings, and the class discussions that were always lively and generative and built off our Canvas reading reflections. This course was a narrative of history and each class built off the one before it seamlessly. Can't think of any weaknesses, except I wish we had more time together. The final research paper was also so fun to write.

Professor Hinton is wonderful and so knowledgeable. She is a strength of the course, and the syllabus is excellent. My only criticism is that sometimes we did activities in class that meant we couldnt discuss the reading.

This course has a lot of readings, though the selections are very thoughtfully chosen and speak to each other week-to-week. Unfortunately, much of class time is not necessarily spent engaging the readings in a very direct manner. I'd suggest that the number of readings be cut down or made optional. I think more direction going into the mid-term assignment may be helpful. The strengths include having the opportunity to hear Professor Hinton engage these issues alongside the class and hear from classmates who are oftentimes doing critical work that's related as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It's a great topic, the readings are interesting, and it's fun to hear Professor Hinton give context to her own work and research as you're discussing it.

YES! This course was an incredible community and I had the best time and learned so much. I will never forget what I learned with Prof. Hinton this semester, and I know I will use all this knowledge in my future. It is essential for all Americans to understand the history of our carceral system, and this course will give you the knowledge of that history and then motivate you to go out into the world and do something about it.
Yes! If you get in, take it.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who's able to get a seat. While it is a lot of work, you will learn so much. Especially if you have related academic or professional interests, you'd be remiss for not trying to take the class.

Simply put, yes. I truly believe the readings from the class and the incredible people I learned from (including prof Hinton) have changed the trajectory of my academic and personal life for the better

Prof. Hinton is a great instructor with really amazing insights and knowledge of the material. All of the other students in the class were also deeply committed to the issues focused on in the course which helped to enrich discussion. Could not recommend enough!

extras.title: HIST 192J 01 - Wars on Crime, Drugs, & Gangs
